JUNE WEEK COMMITTEE TO DECIDE
LOTTERY TODAY IN FRONT OF BARN
All roads lead to the Barn today.
At lunch time all those who are
financially interested will gather in
front of "Doc's" establishment to
Witness the drawings of the June
Week benefit. The investors, lured
on by the baggy trousers, exhibited
in the Van windows, are becoming
impatient at the delay and great excitement is expected as the winners
of the fifty, fifteen, and ten dollar
Prizes are announced.
This drawing is the first step in
.the program by which the June
Week Committee is endeavoring to
reduce the price of tickets. Last
Year they were twenty dollars, but
the Committee hopes to realize its
Plans of making this year's price
One which can be to some degree
covered by the caution fee of ten
dollars, which will be returned
about the time that the tickets are
Put on sale.
"No trouble or expense will be
Spared," said W. C. Gardner. chairMan of the committee, "to make

the 1925 June Week a worthy successor of the tradition instituted by
the Class of '23 and carried on by
last year's seniors." He, also, for
the benefit of new students, pointed
out the 'apparent fact that June
Week is for the good of all undergraduate classes, although the Seniors take all of the financial responsibility. June Week, as he pointed
out, has already become the outstanding social event of the college
year, but it is not yet so firmly established that it can be successful
without the full support of all of
the student body.
NOTICES
COTILLION CLUB
The Cotillion Club will hold a
Christmas dance on Saturday,
December 20 at 9 P. M. in the
C. E. Hall. $1.00 per couple.
BARNSTORMERS
Important meeting of all candidates for production, art, and
business staffs of Barnstormers
Club Monday at 12.20 in Studio.

Held on Monday

Gordon Post, John Finger and
Alan Gump were again nominated
by the Senior Class last Monday
to fill the vacancy in the Student
Council caused by the election of
Calhoun as class president. The
same three men were nominated
about a month ago, but the vote
was so close that the election
had dragged on until last week
when, owing to an illegality of
some of the votes, the Student
Council decided to reopen the
no
Calhoun Presents Insurance Plan

President Calhoun brought before the class a plan of class insurance. In his report he stated
that if each Senior should take
out a policy of $250, the yearly
cost for twenty-five years would
be about $10. At the end of that
time, the class would turn over to
the University a fund of $25,000,
to be specifically used for undergraduate purposes.
George Hess, in a report on the
"Hullabaloo," stated that the year
book is progressing in a very satisfactory manner. One-third of
the "ads" are contracted, most of
the pictures have been taken, and
all of the write-ups have been
turned in. The most pressing
need at present is capital. At this
point "Don" Reese, class treasurer, announced that class dues to
finance the publication should be
paid at once.
Sophomores Meet at Same Time

At the same hour the Sophomore class took up the question of
enforcement of regulations. President Cleaveland pointed out the
consequences of lax discipline on
the part of the class. If no improvement is brought about, the
Student Council has decided to extend the regulations until Easter.
"If such a thing should happen,"
Cleaveland predicted, "both the
prestige of the Sophomores and
the spirit of ,the Freshmen will
suffer." It was the unanimous decision of the class that each member should back up the pep committee in keeping the Frosh in
line.
Soph Basketball Abandoned

The question of organizing a
basketball team was brought up,
but on account of the lack of facilities or equipment, the proposition was dropped.
The motion was made and
passed that the secretary should
send a letter to George Darley,
thanking him for the services he
rendered in coaching the class
football team. A collection was
taken up for some suitable gift for
Sergeant Hendricks, who took
Darley's P. T. classes during the
week that he was coaching the
team.
Treasurer Kleff urged the
prompt payment of dues, since
money is needed for last year's
"Hullabaloo" and for the Student
Council fee.

With Football Season Over Hopkins Athletes Devote Whole Attention to Indian Game and Track. Lacrosse Squad
to Practice During the Holidays
Now that King Football (and the Duchess Cyril) have deserted
America the royalty-craving populace turns to new aristocrats. At Johns
Hopkins this is represented by the renewed attention paid to two forgotten favorites among the peers of 'sport. Both Lacrosse and Track
will soon have the undivided attention of their retinues. These two
sports have lagged while the pigskin bounded on its crazy course across
the turf, and both are now to be taken up in earnest in preparation for
the coming months. Lacrosse and Track at present are the only official
sports which are scheduled to hold winter practice—the swimming team
being independent of the A. A. Board is not included.

The showing of the team as a
whole was far superior to that
made in the first match last year,
said Coach Sherwood. Though
the scores from the kneeling position were slightly lower than
those of the 1923-24 season's opening match, the standing shots
were greatly improved.
Torres Wins First Place

By totalling 373 for his shots
in the four positions, Torres won
individual first place. Torres
joined the Rifle Club last year,
and about this time was shooting
75 prone. Under the coaching ot
Lieutenant Sherwood,and througn
hard, diligent practice, he has developed into one of the best and
most consistent shots on the team.
His 93 was the highest kneeling
score of the match. Second honors went to White, with 370. In
addition to placing second, White
turned in the only perfect sitting
score fired. The highest total
from standing was made by Baird,
who placed fourth.
As an added incentive to the
team, Lieutenant Sherwood has
offered a year's membership in the
National Rifle Association to the
man shooting the highest score in
each match. No man, however,
will be eligible for two years'
membership, so in case one man
wins in two or more matches, the
next highest on the list will receive the award.
Steck Will Strengthen Team

The Syracuse match, on January 10, will see a stronger team in
the field, as Captain Steck, who
has been unable to fire so far this
year, will compete. Steck is, without a doubt, the best shot in the
University, so his return to active
participation will be eagerly awaited. The targets in the match with
the University of West Virginia
will be completed today, having
been started last Tuesday.
Scores of the first ten men in
the Chicago match will be found
on page 3.

Thirty Report Regularly

Thirty candidates have been reporting regularly to Strauss field.
These include Bates, Sanderson,
M. Cone, Draper and Gerstmeyer,
attack men; Kaufholtz and Summers, centers, and Milbourn and
Vogel of the defense, all of whom
have had the advantage of at least
one year's experience. Sidney
Cone, last year's goalkeeper, has
been working with the attack this
fall and gives promise of developing into a first class player. Captain Turnbull has been resting
since the football season, but is
expected to join the squad shortly.
The coaching committee this
year consists of Ray Van Orman,
head, with Reaney Wolfe and Milton MacDaniels acting as assistants. William C. Schmeisser retains the chairmanship of the advisory committee.
Track Squad Meets

At a special meeting Monday in
the M. E. Building, the track
squad mapped out a program for
the winter. Coach Huntley Lloyd
gave a short talk about track practice in general and track practice
down at the Fifth Regiment Armory in particular.
"What we want to do this winter," said Coach Lloyd, "is to concentrate on the fundamental
things about running. There are
probably men here who are not
veterans in the sport and who
need first of all to be drilled in the
rudiments of good conditioning.
The occasional monotony of this
sort of practice Is always well repaid by results in the future."
Coach Lloyd was particularly
anxious that the squad be increased to about three times its
present number. He said that although there were several experienced men in the group a first
teamn has not been picked and
there are plenty of places open to
the fellows who keep in trim
through the winter. "In track,"

JUNE WEEK COMMITTEE TO DECIDE
LOTTERY TODAY IN FRONT OF BARN
All roads lead to the Barn today.
At lunch time all those who are
financially interested will gather in
front of "Doc's" establishment to
Witness the drawings of the June
Week benefit. The investors, lured
on by the baggy trousers, exhibited
in the Van windows, are becoming
impatient at the delay and great excitement is expected as the winners
of the fifty, fifteen, and ten dollar
Prizes are announced.
This drawing is the first step in
.the program by which the June
Week Committee is endeavoring to
reduce the price of tickets. Last
Year they were twenty dollars, but
the Committee hopes to realize its
Plans of making this year's price
One which can be to some degree
covered by the caution fee of ten
dollars, which will be returned
about the time that the tickets are
Put on sale.
"No trouble or expense will be
Spared," said W. C. Gardner. chairMan of the committee, "to make

the 1925 June Week a worthy successor of the tradition instituted by
the Class of '23 and carried on by
last year's seniors." He, also, for
the benefit of new students, pointed
out the 'apparent fact that June
Week is for the good of all undergraduate classes, although the Seniors take all of the financial responsibility. June Week, as he pointed
out, has already become the outstanding social event of the college
year, but it is not yet so firmly established that it can be successful
without the full support of all of
the student body.
NOTICES
COTILLION CLUB
The Cotillion Club will hold a
Christmas dance on Saturday,
December 20 at 9 P. M. in the
C. E. Hall. $1.00 per couple.
BARNSTORMERS
Important meeting of all candidates for production, art, and
business staffs of Barnstormers
Club Monday at 12.20 in Studio.

Held on Monday

Gordon Post, John Finger and
Alan Gump were again nominated
by the Senior Class last Monday
to fill the vacancy in the Student
Council caused by the election of
Calhoun as class president. The
same three men were nominated
about a month ago, but the vote
was so close that the election
had dragged on until last week
when, owing to an illegality of
some of the votes, the Student
Council decided to reopen the
no
Calhoun Presents Insurance Plan

President Calhoun brought before the class a plan of class insurance. In his report he stated
that if each Senior should take
out a policy of $250, the yearly
cost for twenty-five years would
be about $10. At the end of that
time, the class would turn over to
the University a fund of $25,000,
to be specifically used for undergraduate purposes.
George Hess, in a report on the
"Hullabaloo," stated that the year
book is progressing in a very satisfactory manner. One-third of
the "ads" are contracted, most of
the pictures have been taken, and
all of the write-ups have been
turned in. The most pressing
need at present is capital. At this
point "Don" Reese, class treasurer, announced that class dues to
finance the publication should be
paid at once.
Sophomores Meet at Same Time

At the same hour the Sophomore class took up the question of
enforcement of regulations. President Cleaveland pointed out the
consequences of lax discipline on
the part of the class. If no improvement is brought about, the
Student Council has decided to extend the regulations until Easter.
"If such a thing should happen,"
Cleaveland predicted, "both the
prestige of the Sophomores and
the spirit of ,the Freshmen will
suffer." It was the unanimous decision of the class that each member should back up the pep committee in keeping the Frosh in
line.
Soph Basketball Abandoned

The question of organizing a
basketball team was brought up,
but on account of the lack of facilities or equipment, the proposition was dropped.
The motion was made and
passed that the secretary should
send a letter to George Darley,
thanking him for the services he
rendered in coaching the class
football team. A collection was
taken up for some suitable gift for
Sergeant Hendricks, who took
Darley's P. T. classes during the
week that he was coaching the
team.
Treasurer Kleff urged the
prompt payment of dues, since
money is needed for last year's
"Hullabaloo" and for the Student
Council fee.

With Football Season Over Hopkins Athletes Devote Whole Attention to Indian Game and Track. Lacrosse Squad
to Practice During the Holidays
Now that King Football (and the Duchess Cyril) have deserted
America the royalty-craving populace turns to new aristocrats. At Johns
Hopkins this is represented by the renewed attention paid to two forgotten favorites among the peers of 'sport. Both Lacrosse and Track
will soon have the undivided attention of their retinues. These two
sports have lagged while the pigskin bounded on its crazy course across
the turf, and both are now to be taken up in earnest in preparation for
the coming months. Lacrosse and Track at present are the only official
sports which are scheduled to hold winter practice—the swimming team
being independent of the A. A. Board is not included.

The showing of the team as a
whole was far superior to that
made in the first match last year,
said Coach Sherwood. Though
the scores from the kneeling position were slightly lower than
those of the 1923-24 season's opening match, the standing shots
were greatly improved.
Torres Wins First Place

By totalling 373 for his shots
in the four positions, Torres won
individual first place. Torres
joined the Rifle Club last year,
and about this time was shooting
75 prone. Under the coaching ot
Lieutenant Sherwood,and througn
hard, diligent practice, he has developed into one of the best and
most consistent shots on the team.
His 93 was the highest kneeling
score of the match. Second honors went to White, with 370. In
addition to placing second, White
turned in the only perfect sitting
score fired. The highest total
from standing was made by Baird,
who placed fourth.
As an added incentive to the
team, Lieutenant Sherwood has
offered a year's membership in the
National Rifle Association to the
man shooting the highest score in
each match. No man, however,
will be eligible for two years'
membership, so in case one man
wins in two or more matches, the
next highest on the list will receive the award.
Steck Will Strengthen Team

The Syracuse match, on January 10, will see a stronger team in
the field, as Captain Steck, who
has been unable to fire so far this
year, will compete. Steck is, without a doubt, the best shot in the
University, so his return to active
participation will be eagerly awaited. The targets in the match with
the University of West Virginia
will be completed today, having
been started last Tuesday.
Scores of the first ten men in
the Chicago match will be found
on page 3.

Thirty Report Regularly

Thirty candidates have been reporting regularly to Strauss field.
These include Bates, Sanderson,
M. Cone, Draper and Gerstmeyer,
attack men; Kaufholtz and Summers, centers, and Milbourn and
Vogel of the defense, all of whom
have had the advantage of at least
one year's experience. Sidney
Cone, last year's goalkeeper, has
been working with the attack this
fall and gives promise of developing into a first class player. Captain Turnbull has been resting
since the football season, but is
expected to join the squad shortly.
The coaching committee this
year consists of Ray Van Orman,
head, with Reaney Wolfe and Milton MacDaniels acting as assistants. William C. Schmeisser retains the chairmanship of the advisory committee.
Track Squad Meets

At a special meeting Monday in
the M. E. Building, the track
squad mapped out a program for
the winter. Coach Huntley Lloyd
gave a short talk about track practice in general and track practice
down at the Fifth Regiment Armory in particular.
"What we want to do this winter," said Coach Lloyd, "is to concentrate on the fundamental
things about running. There are
probably men here who are not
veterans in the sport and who
need first of all to be drilled in the
rudiments of good conditioning.
The occasional monotony of this
sort of practice Is always well repaid by results in the future."
Coach Lloyd was particularly
anxious that the squad be increased to about three times its
present number. He said that although there were several experienced men in the group a first
teamn has not been picked and
there are plenty of places open to
the fellows who keep in trim
through the winter. "In track,"
